questions.text:
Match the following description of ulcers with their causative organisms.


	
		
			
			1.Painful vesicular lesions
			
			
			a) Syphilis
			
		
		
			
			2.Painless, beefy red ulcers with rolled edges.
			
			
			b) Chancroid
			
		
		
			
			3.Painless genital ulcer with indurated base.
			
			
			c) Genital herpes
			
		
		
			4.Soft, painful genital ulcer with irregular borders.
			d) Granuloma inguinale
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

Explanation:

The correct match of the clinical description with their disease is shown below.

Ulcer Description Causative Organism
1. Painful vesicular lesions c) Genital herpes
2. Painless, beefy red ulcers with rolled edges d) Granuloma inguinale
3. Painless genital ulcer with indurated base a) Syphilis
4. Soft, painful genital ulcer with irregular borders b) Chancroid

Genital herpes presents with painful vesicular lesions & blisters which can burst and cause ulcer formation. It is most commonly caused by HSV-2 > HSV-1. The given image below shows genital herpes.

Granuloma inguinale is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy ulcers that may bleed on touch. Microscopically, it shows Donovan body with a safety-pin appearance. The given image shows the clinical picture of the ulcer and Donovan bodies.

 

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum. It occurs in various stages such as primary, secondary, and tertiary. The primary lesion appears as a regularly edged, regularly based, hard, painless, and button‐like ulceration measuring up to 1 cm in diameter. The ulcer is often surrounded by a narrow, red border 1–2 mm wide. The given image shows the primary ulcer.

Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. multiple, superficial, tender, soft, ragged ulcers which bleed on manipulation.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presents with vaginal discharge that is frothy, yellow-green in colour and has a foul odour. She reports mild vaginal itching and discomfort during urination. A per speculum reveals the image shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trichomonas vaginalis

Explanation:

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It typically presents with the frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a foul odor, along with vaginal itching and discomfort during urination.
  • The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.
  • The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

Features

Bacterial Vaginosis

Trichomoniasis

Candidiasis (Yeast Infection)

Discharge

Thin, greyish-white, homogenous discharge

Frothy, yellow-green, often malodorous discharge

Thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge, often odourless

Odor

Fishy odour, particularly noticeable after intercourse

A foul odour can be strong and unpleasant

Usually no significant odor

Genital Itching/Irritation

May or may not be present

Common

Common, along with redness and swelling of the vulva

pH of Vaginal Discharge

Elevated (usually above 4.5)

Elevated (usually above 4.5)

Acidic (4.0 to 4.5)

Clue Cells on Microscopy

Present (epithelial cells with adherent bacteria)

Absent

Absent

Microscopic Pathogen

Overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (Gardnerella vaginalis)(option D)

Protozoan parasite (Trichomonas vaginalis)

Overgrowth of Candida species (Candida albicans most common)(Option A)

Treatment

Secnidazole 2g SOD

Metronidazole 2g single dose PO

Secnidazole 2g +fluconazole 150mg

 

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C) infection can present with vaginal discharge (which may be yellow or green), pelvic pain, and dysuria.

questions.text:
A 28 year old sexually active man presents with painful genital lesions as shown in the image. He reports a tingling sensation and burning pain in the genital area preceding the appearance of the ulcers.

Which of the following is the most characteristic finding for his condition?

choices.text: The presence of multinucleated giant cells on the Tzanck smear
Presence of bacterial colonies, "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain
Donovan bodies within Pund cells on Gram stain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The presence of multinucleated giant cells on the Tzanck smear

Explanation:

  • Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear (See image)are characteristic of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, particularly herpes genitalis

 

  • TZANCK smear

  • The presence of painful genital lesions, along with a tingling sensation and burning pain preceding the appearance of ulcers, is highly suggestive of HSV infection.
  • The image shows multiple vesicles and pustules with a coalescing vesicles and erosions as seen in herpes genitalis

Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused primarily by HSV-2, although HSV-1 can also be responsible. It is characterised by the infection of genital skin or mucosa

  • Clinical features:
    • Multiple, painful, non-indurated vesicles that may rupture, forming coalescing vesicles or polycyclic erosions.
    • Bilateral tender lymphadenopathy is common.
    • Males: Painful penile ulcerations affecting the glans, prepuce and shaft of the penis
    • Females: Involves external genitalia, vulva, vagina and cervix. Accompanied by dysuria
  • Diagnosis: Tzanck smear, revealing multinucleated giant cells, a characteristic feature.
  • Serological testing, such as ELISA for HSV glycoprotein, can also aid in diagnosis.
  • Treatment typically involves antiviral medications like acyclovir (400mg TDS), administered for 7-10 days for primary infection and 5 days for secondary infection.

Presence of bacterial colonies, "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain (Option B): This finding is characteristic of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, which leads to the formation of painful genital ulcers.

   

Donovan bodies within Pund cells on Gram stain (Option C): This finding is characteristic of granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis, caused by the bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis. Donovan bodies are intracellular inclusions seen within macrophages, representing aggregates of the causative organism giving safety pin appearence.

Clue cells on saline mount (Option D): Clue cells are epithelial cells covered with bacteria, typically seen in bacterial vaginosis (BV), caused by Gardenella vaginalis.

questions.text: A 35 year old truck driver presents to the clinic with complaints of a painful genital lesion that has been progressively enlarging over the past few weeks. Upon examination, you note a tender ulcerative lesion with undermined edges and a base covered by a greyish exudate. Additionally, there are enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes palpable unilaterally. The patient reports a recent sexual encounter with another male truck driver. Which of the following sexually transmitted infections is most likely to present with this clinical manifestation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chancroid

Explanation: 

  • Chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch.
  • Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy.
  • The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo.
  • Diagnosis
    • Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance.
    • Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • Treatment.
    • Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram
    • OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose)

 

Ulcer

Lymph Node

  

Syphilis - treponema Pallidum (Option A)

Painless genital ulcer called a chancre

Non-tender and rubbery in consistency.

Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (Option B)

Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas

Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection)

Herpes Simplex (Option C)

Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions

Multiple, enlarged and inflamed.

Lymphogranuloma Venerum

(Chlamydia)

Solitary and painless.
  • Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material.
  • Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents to the clinic with painless, beefy-red ulcers on his genitals. He reports that the lesions have been progressively enlarging over the past few weeks. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oral Azithromycin

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of a male with painless, beefy-red ulcers on his genitals with progressive enlargement is suggestive of granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. The drug of choice for this condition is oral azithromycin.

Donovanosis, also known as granuloma inguinale, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis bacteria. The characteristic clinical presentation includes painless, beefy-red ulcers that can bleed on touch, with rolled edges and a granular base.

Prolonged antibiotic treatment is often necessary. Antibiotics must be given for 3-6 weeks till the ulcer is healed. Drugs include

 

First-line

Azithromycin 1g once weekly (or)

Azithromycin 500mg daily
 

Second-line

Doxycycline 100mg BD (or)

Erythromycin 500mg QID (or)

Cotrimoxazole 960mg BD

 

Incorrect options:

Intramuscular penicillin G (Option B) is used in the treatment of syphilis.

Intramuscular ceftriaxone (Option C) is used in the treatment of gonococcal infections.

Oral doxycycline (Option D) can be used in the second-line treatment of donovanosis.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presents to a clinic with complaints of painless genital ulcer. He reports that the ulcers have been present for several weeks and have been progressively increasing in size. He also mentions that the ulcers bleed easily upon touch and are not indurated. A picture of the ulcer is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Donovanosis

Explanation:

The image depicts a beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base.

  • The presence of a painless, beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base that bleeds easily on touch, indicates a diagnosis of Donovanosis.

Characteristic

Description

Causative Agent

Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium

Clinical Presentation

Painless ulcers or nodules in genital, perianal, or inguinal regions; ulceration with beefy red, granular base

Progression

Slowly progressive, may lead to extensive tissue destruction if untreated

Complications

Genital deformity, lymphatic obstruction, secondary bacterial infections

Diagnostic Tests

Tissue biopsy, Wright or Giemsa staining of tissue samples, PCR for bacterial DNA

Treatment

Doxycycline (200mg daily) or azithromycin (1g once a week)for 3 weeks

 

Characteristic

Donovanosis

Syphilis (Option A)

Chancroid (Option B)

LGV (Option C)

Causative Agent

Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium

Treponema pallidum bacterium

Haemophilus ducreyi bacterium

Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars L1-L3)

Appearance of Ulcer

Beefy red, painless, exuberant granulation tissue

Painless, solitary, firm, round ulcer

Multiple necrotic based non indurated with undermined edges and bleeds on touch

Painless herpetiform transient ulcer

Images

questions.text: A 32 year old male presents to a primary care clinic with complaints of urethral discharge and dysuria. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. On examination, you note purulent discharge from the urethra. Which colour kit would be most appropriate for initial management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Grey

Explanation:

The grey colour kit in the NACO syndromic management approach is used for urethral discharge in males, which is suggestive of possible gonococcal infection (gonorrhoea).

STI Color Coded Kits under NACP- 2024:

questions.text: A 32 year old woman presents with complaints of vaginal discharge and a fishy odour. She denies any genital itching or irritation. On examination, you notice the discharge coats the vaginal walls as shown in the image. There is no erythema or inflammation noted. Out of the following, which is the single most reliable predictor to support the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Presence of clue cells on wet mount microscopy
Positive whiff test (amine odour) with 10% KOH solution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Presence of clue cells on wet mount microscopy

Explanation: The presence of clue cells on saline wet mount is the single most reliable predictor of bacterial vaginosis.

  • Indicators towards the diagnosis:
    • Presence of fishy-smelling, vaginal discharge without a history of pruritus
    • The image shows a thin, homogenous whitish discharge that coats the walls, characteristic of bacterial vaginosis
  • Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are studded with adherent coccobacilli. This gives the cells a stippled, fuzzy appearance. The presence of these cells indicates bacterial infection of the vagina.
  • Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis: 

         

Amsel's criteria for bacterial vaginosis (BV):

  1. Thin, greyish-white vaginal discharge.
  2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5
  3. Presence of clue cells on wet mount microscopy and
  4. Positive whiff test (amine odour) with 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution.

Presence of at least three of the above findings is needed to make a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis

Nugent’s score

It is the gold standard test for bacterial vaginosis but is not used in clinical practice as it requires more expertise. This score involves a gram stain smear of vaginal discharge.

Score

Lactobacillus morphotype/ hpf

Gardnerella and Bacteroides morphotypes/ hpf

Curved bacteria (Mobiluncus)/ hpf

0

>30

0

0

1

5-30

<1

1-5

2

1-4

1-4

>5

3

<1

5-30

  

4

0

>30

  

Interpretation:

  • 7 to 10: Bacterial vaginosis
  • 4 to 6: Indeterminate
  • 0 to 3: Normal.

Options B, C and D: While all the options are part of Amsel's criteria, presence of clue cells is most diagnostic, as other features may be seen with other types of vaginal discharge. Presence of clue cells >20% is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman with a medical history significant for diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with complaints of vaginal itching and thick, white, curd-like discharge. Physical examination reveals no signs of inflammation or lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaginal Candidiasis

Explanation:

  • Vaginal candidiasis, (yeast infection/ vaginal thrush) is caused by overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans.
  • Women with diabetes are at higher risk of developing yeast infections due to elevated blood sugar levels, which provide a favourable environment for yeast growth.
  • The symptoms typically include vaginal itching, thick, white, curd-like discharge, and sometimes redness and swelling of the vulva.
  • The absence of inflammation or lesions on examination further supports the diagnosis of vaginal candidiasis
  • Unlike other vaginal discharges, Vaginal pH is usually acidic.
  • Treatment:
    • Topical azole antifungals: Clotrimazole, miconazole, econazole, or tioconazole creams or suppositories
    • Oral azole antifungals: Fluconazole is an effective oral antifungal medication that may be prescribed as a single-dose regimen (150 mg) or as multiple doses depending on the severity of the infection.

 

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Option A):

  • It is characterized by a thin, greyish-white discharge with a characteristic fishy odour, known as "whiff test" positivity.

Trichomoniasis (Option B):

  • Trichomonal vaginitis typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a characteristic foul odour, often described as "musty."
  • Additionally, patients with trichomoniasis may experience vulvar itching, dyspareunia, and dysuria.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection (Option D):

  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection typically presents with mucopurulent cervical discharge.
  • It may lead to complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) if left untreated.

questions.text: A 28 year old sexually active male presents to the clinic with a painless single lesion on his genitals. On examination, the healthcare provider observes single small, round, painless ulcer with raised edges and a clean base as shown below. The patient denies any recent travel, but he reports having unprotected sexual contact with multiple partners in the past month. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intramuscular Penicillin G Benzathine

Explanation :

  • Based on the clinical presentation of single painless genital ulcer with raised edges and a clean base in a sexually active individual, the most likely diagnosis is syphilis, specifically primary syphilis.
  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum.
  • The treatment of choice for all stages of syphilis, including primary syphilis, is penicillin. In this case, intramuscular Penicillin G Benzathine is the recommended treatment.

Other Options:

Option A: Doxycycline is effective for treating genital ulcers like donovosis.

Option B: Oral Azithromycin is not the first-line treatment for primary syphilis. Azithromycin is also used for the treatment of Chlamydia and Gonorrhoea.

Option D: Oral Acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections that present with multiple painful ulcers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old sexually active female presents with dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and mild cervical discharge on per speculum examination.. She denies fever or abdominal pain. A urinalysis reveals pyuria, but no bacteria are seen on Gram staining of the discharge. Which of the following agents is the first-line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and absence of bacteria on Gram stain suggest Chlamydia trachomatis as the likely cause of non-gonococcal cervicitis. The first-line treatment is a single dose of Azithromycin (1g orally).
  • The diagnosis of NGU/NGC requires the exclusion of gonorrheal infection. This can be achieved with a gram stain that lacks gram-negative diplococci or by any negative gonorrhea test (culture, nucleic acid testing, among others).

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D-K are the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis. In females, it can cause various manifestations such as:

  • Mucopurulent cervicitis (most common).
  • It may progress to endometritis, salpingitis (fallopian tube), pelvic inflammatory disease, and finally pelvic peritonitis.
  • Perihepatitis (Fitz–Hugh–Curtis syndrome).

First-line management involves a single oral dose of azithromycin 1g stat. It is preferred due to its greater effectiveness and lower cost.

The table below shows the management of uncomplicated chlamydial infections:

Non-pregnant

First line: Azithromycin 1g single dose

Second line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 7 days

Third line: Ofloxacin 200-300mg BD x 7 days

Pregnancy

First line: Azithromycin 1g oral single dose

Second line: Amoxicillin 500mg TDS x 7 days

 

Ceftriaxone (Option B) is used for the treatment of gonococcal infections.

Fluconazole (Option C) is used for the treatment of vaginal candidiasis.

Doxycycline (Option D) is also highly effective for treating uncomplicated chlamydial infections. It is used when azithromycin is not available or there is a history of allergies. The recommended dose is 100 mg BD x 7 days.

questions.text: A 28 year old male presents to the STD clinic with a history of swelling in the inguinal region as shown in the image below. He has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse in the past few months and reports a painless ulcer, which healed without scarring. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection
Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy
Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy

Explanation:

The given clinical presentation of a male with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, swelling in the inguinal region (inguinal lymphadenopathy) and a painless ulcer that has healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The incorrect statement is that it presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV): 

  • It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2). It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection.
  • The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days, and the disease presents in three stages, described in the table below:

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

3-30 days

Days-weeks

Years after a chronic, untreated infection

Small papule/pustule/
Non-indurated ulcer at the site of inoculation which heals spontaneously with no scarring.
  • Lymphatic involvement of nodes that drain the primary lesion.
  • Classic form: Tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal and/or femoral adenopathy (Groove sign of Greenblatt).
  • The lymph nodes may coalesce to form a bubo or abscesses that may rupture spontaneously with the development of
    Fistulae or sinus tracts.
  • There may be systemic features such as malaise and fever.

Lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation leads to fistula formation, strictures, and disfiguring conditions such as genital elephantiasis and esthiomene, which refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia.
  • Diagnosis of LGV can be confirmed by the Nucelic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT). Antibody detection by real-time PCR can also be done. Treatment includes:
    • First line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 21 days.
    • Second line: Erythromycin 500mg 4 times a day x 21 days.
    • Third line: Azithromycin 1g weekly once x 21 days.

 

Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3 (Option A): This statement is true; these specific serovars are the causative agents of LGV.

Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection (Option B): This statement is true; co-infections with other STIs, including HCV, are possible in individuals with LGV.

Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease (Option D): This statement is true; esthiomene (genital elephantiasis) is a recognized chronic complication of untreated or persistent LGV infection.

questions.text: A 28 year old female presents with lower abdominal pain, dyspareunia, and cervical motion tenderness. She also reports that she has been unable to conceive despite actively trying for the past 18 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chlamydia infection

Explanation:

The symptoms described in the stem, along with the patient's inability to conceive despite actively trying, raise suspicion of chlamydia infection.

  • Chlamydial pelvic inflammatory disease often presents asymptomatically but can cause symptoms such as lower abdominal pain, dyspareunia, and cervical motion tenderness.
  • These symptoms, along with the patient's reported inability to conceive despite actively trying for the past 18 months, raise suspicion for chlamydial pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can lead to fallopian tube damage and subsequent infertility.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs). It is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis

  • Clinical features in females: Although it is mostly asymptomatic, it can present in the following forms:
    • Cervicitis
    • Urethritis
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease
    • Perihepatitis
    • Pregnancy complications
  • Clinical features in males:
    • Urethritis
    • Epididymitis
    • Prostatitis
  • Common features:
    • Conjunctivitis
    • Pharyngitis
    • Proctitis
    • Genital lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Diagnosis is made through nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of genital samples.

 

Genital herpes (Option A) presents with multiple, painful, non-indurated, umbilicated vesicles that rupture to form coalescing vesicles or polycyclic erosions.

Syphilis (Option C) presents as painless genital ulcers (chancre).

Trichomoniasis (Option D) presents with frothy discharge, vulvar itching, and strawberry cervix.

questions.text: A 28 year old sexually active male presents with dysuria and urethral discharge which is purulent, profuse, thick and creamy. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IM Ceftriaxone

Explanation:

Given the symptoms and risk factors, the most likely diagnosis is gonorrhoea. IM ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic, is the recommended treatment. Ceftriaxone is typically given as a single dose, often combined with azithromycin to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis.

In case of chlamydia the urethral discharge is mucoid/mucopurulent.

Treatment regimens in Neisseria infection:

Treatment Regimen

Dosage/Duration

Uncomplicated Gonorrhea

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular)

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

 

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily,

Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily

For 7 days

Note: Azithromycin is preferred if chlamydia coinfection is suspected.

Alternative Regimen

Cefixime 400 mg orally

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

 

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily

Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily

For 7 days

Extragenital Gonorrhea (Pharyngeal or Rectal)

Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular)

+

Azithromycin 1 g orally

Single dose

Single dose

OR

Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily

For 7 days

Oral fluconazole (Option A): Fluconazole is used for treating fungal infections like vaginal candidiasis.

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G (Option B): Penicillin G is used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhoea.

Oral Azithromycin (Option C): Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for gonorrhoea but is not the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 22 year old sexually active woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vaginal discharge and pelvic pain. She reports having multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of condoms. On examination, the healthcare provider notices purulent vaginal discharge and tenderness on pelvic examination. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gonorrhea

Explanation:

  • Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Additionally, the history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use is suggestive of a higher risk for STIs, including gonorrhoea.

Gram stain showing Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Neisseria Gonorrhoea:

Characteristic

Description

Bacterium

Gram-negative diplococcus

Clinical Presentation

Genital discharge (purulent), dysuria, pelvic pain, rectal symptoms

Complications

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), epididymitis, prostatitis, disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI)

Transmission

Primarily through sexual contact (vaginal, anal, oral) with an infected individual

Risk Factors

Unprotected sex, multiple sexual partners, history of gonorrhoea

Diagnosis

In males, by gram stain(gram negative intracellular diplococci) and culture and in females by culture.

Multiplex PCR 

Treatment

SOD cefixime 400mg or intramuscular ceftriaxone 125/250mg as SD

 

Bacterial vaginosis (Option A) is characterized by a thin, greyish-white vaginal discharge with a fishy odour, but it does not present with purulent discharge or intracellular gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain.

Candidiasis (Option B) is a fungal infection that causes vaginal itching and thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge.

Trichomoniasis (Option C) is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis and typically presents with frothy, yellow-green, malodorous discharge.

questions.text: A newborn infant presents with symptoms suggestive of congenital syphilis. The mother had untreated syphilis during pregnancy. Which of the following is not a manifestation of early-onset congenital syphilis in newborns?

choices.text: Inflammation of oral and nasal mucosa

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hutchinson’s Triad

  • Hutchinson’s Triad is a feature of the late-onset congenital syphilis.
  • Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman with untreated syphilis passes the infection to her fetus during pregnancy. The bacterium Treponema pallidum can affect various organ systems in the newborn.
  • The lesions in Congenital syphilis can be classified as Early onset (within 2 years after birth) and Late onset (after 2 years of birth).

Lesions in Early Onset Congenital Syphilis: (Options A, B, C ruled out)

  • Vesiculo Bullous rash - Over palms & soles (aka SYPHILITIC PEMPHIGUS)
  • Inflammation of oral and nasal mucosa
  • Continuous discharge from the nose is called snuffles.
  • Wimberger Sign (Bilateral Medial Tibial Erosions)
  • Osteochondritis & Peri Osteochondritis (Pseudo Paralysis of Parrot - Child not able to move)

Lesions in Late Onset Congenital Syphilis

  • Hutchison’s Triad: Peg-shaped incisors, interstitial keratitis, and deafness
  • Mulberry Molars
  • Deformed nose
  • Rhagades: Fissures around the mouth
  • Frontal bossing / Olympian bow
  • Higoumenakis Sign (Unilateral Medial Clavicle Periostitis)
  • Cluttons Joint (Painless)
  • Sabre Tibia (Anterior Tibia Periostitis)

questions.text: A 28 year old man presents to the clinic with a diffuse, maculopapular rash on his palms and soles, as well as fever and sore throat. He reports that the rash developed a few weeks after he noticed a painless ulcer on his genital area, which resolved on its own. The rash is not itchy and does not involve the face. The patient also has white patches in his mouth and a few small, red papules on his genitals. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Secondary Syphilis

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this patient's presentation is secondary syphilis.
  • Secondary syphilis occurs a few weeks to months after the initial infection (primary syphilis) and is characterized by a variety of symptoms, including a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles.
  • Other common features of secondary syphilis include fever, sore throat, and mucous membrane involvement (such as white patches in the mouth). The presence of a painless genital ulcer (chancre) in the history supports the diagnosis.

Characteristic

Primary Syphilis

Secondary Syphilis

Tertiary Syphilis

Causative Agent

Treponema pallidum bacterium

Incubation period

9-90 days after sexual contact

3-12 weeks 

24 months

Clinical features

Single, indurated (button like),painless, clean ulcer which oozes serum on pressure

Coppery hyperpigmented, scaly macules or hyperkeratotic papules on palms and soles.

condyloma lata in perianal and other intertriginous regions

Gumma formation on skin and mucosa ,neurosyphilis, uncomplicated aortitis ,aortic insufficiency ,aneurysm ,coronary stenosis, hepatic gumma

Diagnostic Tests

Darkground microscopy(cork-screw appearance)

Darkground microscopy

Blood tests (RPR, VDRL), imaging studies

Treatment

Benzathine penicillin 2.4 megaunits deep IM 

In penicillin -sensitive patients-

Men and non -pregnant women-Doxycycline 100mg BD x 14d.

pregnant women-Erythromycin stearate 500mg QDS x 14d
